awd_titl_txt: Non-Equilibrium Transport of Strongly Correlated Electrolytes in Nanopores: Fundamentals and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal sets out a goal to understand the dynamics of nanopore-Room Temperature Ionic Liquids (RTIL) interactions better, in order to improve the ability to design better supercapacitors for energy-storage. The specific objective of this research is to investigate, using atomistic simulations, the electrically-driven transport of RTILs in nanopores and its applications in the charging dynamics of supercapacitors. 

Success of this project can help the development of new energy-storage approaches by providing a better understanding of the fundamentals of RTILs in super-capacitors that use nanoporous materials. The PI has an active plan to train undergraduates, participate in K-12 outreach activities, and to publicly share the PI?s Molecular Dynamics codes for modeling charged interfaces, which is an efficient way of disseminating the outcome of this research.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Room-temperature ionic liquids (RTILs) are a new class of electrolyte consists completely of ions but remains in the liquid state at ambient temperature. Because of their unique properties such as low vapor pressure, excellent thermal stability, and excellent electrochemical stability at high voltage (up to 6V), RTILs are promising candidates for electrochemical devices such as supercapacitors and dye-sensitized solar cells. In many of these devices, the system performance is controlled by the molecular structure, molecular dynamics, and externally driven transport of the RTILs confined in nanoscale environments. These phenomena are within the scope of molecular thermodynamics but are poorly understood because the solvent-free nature of RTILs makes most available theories for electrolytes inapplicable.

In this project, a series of studies have been performed to investigate the structure and transport of RTILs in nano-confinement to fill the gap of existing understanding. In the most important set of studies, we investigated the charging of supercapacitors with RTILs as electrolytes at the single nanopore scale using molecular dynamics simulations. We showed that, when the pore is so narrow that it accommodates only one layer of ions in it, the charging is a process similar to heat diffusion. In sharp contrast to conventional expectations, charging is fast because the diffusion of ions can be an order of magnitude faster than in the bulk, and charging itself is accelerated by the onset of collective modes. We also found that, although many factors affect the ion diffusion, the ion packing typically plays the most important role. These results highlight the importance of understanding the charge dependence of ion diffusion in addition to the pore size dependence. Simulation of the cyclic charging and discharging of single nanopores, which are how supercapacitors are tested experimentally, revealed that such charging and discharging are governed by the interplay between the external field-driven ion transport and the sloshing dynamics of ions inside of the pore. The ion occupancy along the pore length depends strongly on the scan rate and varies cyclically during charging/discharging. Unlike that at equilibrium conditions or low scan rates, charge storage at high scan rates is dominated by counterions while the contribution by co-ions is marginal or negative. These observations help explain the perm-selective charge storage observed experimentally.

In the second most important set of studies, we investigated the structure of humid RTILs confined near electrified interfaces. This study was motivated by the fact that most RTILs are hygroscopic, and even those featuring hydrophobic ions can absorb a large amount of water from the atmosphere. Therefore, the issue of water accumulation, which can potentially lead to side reactions such as water electrolysis, must be addressed in practical application of RTILs in electrochemical devices. Our simulation results revealed that water molecules tend to accumulate within subnanometer distance from charged electrodes. At low amount of water in the bulk, the distributions of ions and of electrostatic potential in the double layer are affected weakly by the presence of water, but the spatial distribution of water molecules is strongly dependent on both. These insights help guide the practical design of supercapacitors based on RTILs.

The above and other results of this project have been published in nine journal papers, shared in many professional meetings, and presented in invited seminars at universities including Rutgers and Harvard. The findings have also been presented to undergraduate students at Virginia Tech. The research code developed in this project for simulations involving polarizable electrodes has been made public free of charge. Three Ph.D. students have been trained in this project and two of them have received their Ph.D. degree already. 

 


Last Modified: 07/02/2018
Modified by: Rui Qiao
